custom_fields.key_topics: academic authorship, academic argument genres (thesis-driven essay, research proposal, and research article), using models, advanced source-based writing, argument analysis, synthesis
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should be able to work comfortably with summary, paraphrase and basic citation methods to support source-based writing; should be familiar with basic argument skills for both reading and writing; should exercise control over language choices and should exercise control over composition processes; should be familiar with a variety of strategies for planning and writing texts.

custom_fields.goals: Genre and Language Knowledge to observe and adapt models for writing your own text that connects with readers.Academic Inquiry and Research Knowledge to construct a relevant academic contribution that comes from inquiry and engagement with multiple existing perspectives.Argument Knowledge to invent and produce reasonable arguments that convince readers in an academic discourse community.Multimodal Knowledge and Collaboration to use visual and oral modes of communication to communicate your argument.Composition and Cognitive Process Knowledge to manage your knowledge and writing processes to meet new rhetorical situations.
custom_fields.relevance: 76-101 is a full-semester course and one of the course options that students can choose to fulfill their First-Year Writing requirement. The other option is to take two half-semester mini courses. If you like the idea of engaging in a sustained focus throughout the semester, this full-semester course may be a good option for you. Our full-semester courses offer students the opportunity to read deeply about a controversial issue or topic. Students acquire strategies for reading, forming research questions, and writing research proposals and articles, in order to contribute an original argument to an ongoing field of inquiry. Some students report a flexible, "marathon" pace throughout the course, driven by the lack of a mid-semester break.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: 1:1 conferences with faculty about your writing

long_desc: Interpretation and Argument is a foundational, inquirydriven writing course that introduces students to a variety of strategies for making compositional decisions in writing and communication. Within the course, students learn genrebased skills applicable to a variety of different fields. Students use a comparative genre analysis method to learn how to use models to take on new writing tasks, including an academic research proposal and a research article that contributes to an ongoing academic conversation. Faculty who teach 76101 typically select texts, ranging from scholarly texts, journalism, and film, about an issue so that students can identify interesting questions for their own research projects. Students should expect explicit, researchbased instruction, practice, and reflection to build knowledge in controlling their writing processes and writing clear, wellsupported, readeroriented arguments. Because the course emphasizes the real stakes of communicating with readers and listeners, students share with their peers both low and high stakes written work within an interactive and collaborative classroom environment. Due to the limits of our schedule, we are unable to meet each students individual preferences for course topics, but we do offer a wide variety from which to choose.
